matched.name: Fibula
matched.summary: The fibula or calf bone is a leg bone on the lateral side of the tibia, to which it is connected above and below.
matched.description: The fibula or calf bone is a leg bone on the lateral side of the tibia, to which it is connected above and below. It is the smaller of the two bones and, in proportion to its length, the most slender of all the long bones. Its upper extremity is small, placed toward the back of the head of the tibia, below the knee joint and excluded from the formation of this joint.

matched.name: Fibularis longus muscle

matched.description: In human anatomy, the fibularis longus (also known as peroneus longus) is a superficial muscle in the lateral compartment of the leg, and acts to evert and plantarflex the ankle. matched.description: In human anatomy, the fibularis tertius (also known as the peroneus tertius) is a muscle in the anterior compartment of the leg. It acts to tilt the sole of the foot away from the midline of the body (eversion) and to pull the foot upward toward the body (dorsiflexion).

matched.name: Popliteus muscle
matched.summary: The popliteus muscle in the leg is used for unlocking the knees when walking, by laterally rotating the femur on the tibia during the closed chain...
matched.description: The popliteus muscle in the leg is used for unlocking the knees when walking, by laterally rotating the femur on the tibia during the closed chain portion of the gait cycle (one with the foot in contact with the ground). In open chain movements (when the involved limb is not in contact with the ground), the popliteus muscle medially rotates the tibia on the femur.
actions: internally rotates tibia on the femur

matched.summary: The posterior talofibular ligament is a ligament that connects the fibula to the talus bone.
matched.description: The posterior talofibular ligament is a ligament that connects the fibula to the talus bone. It runs almost horizontally from the malleolar fossa of the lateral malleolus of the fibula to the lateral tubercle on the posterior surface of the talus. This insertion lies immediately lateral to the groove for the tendon of the flexor hallucis longus. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Posterior_talofibular_ligament

matched.name: Soleus muscle
matched.summary: In humans and some other mammals, the soleus is a powerful muscle in the back part of the lower leg (the calf).
matched.description: In humans and some other mammals, the soleus is a powerful muscle in the back part of the lower leg (the calf). It runs from just below the knee to the heel, and is involved in standing and walking. It is closely connected to the gastrocnemius muscle and some anatomists consider them to be a single muscle, the triceps surae. Its name is derived from the Latin word "solea", meaning "sandal".

matched.description: The tibial collateral ligament (TCL), or Medial collateral ligament (MCL) is one of the four major ligaments of the knee. It is on the medial (inner) side of the knee joint in humans and other primates. Its primary function is to resist outward turning forces on the knee.

matched.name: Subcutaneous bursa of lateral malleolus
matched.summary: A malleolus is the bony prominence on each side of the human ankle.
matched.description: A malleolus is the bony prominence on each side of the human ankle. Each leg is supported by two bones, the tibia on the inner side (medial) of the leg and the fibula on the outer side (lateral) of the leg. The lateral malleolus is the prominence on the outer side of the ankle, formed by the lower end of the fibula. The word malleolus (), plural malleoli (), comes from Latin and means "small hammer". (It is cognate with mallet.)

matched.name: Subcutaneous bursa of lateral malleolus
matched.summary: A malleolus is the bony prominence on each side of the human ankle.
matched.description: A malleolus is the bony prominence on each side of the human ankle. Each leg is supported by two bones, the tibia on the inner side (medial) of the leg and the fibula on the outer side (lateral) of the leg. The lateral malleolus is the prominence on the outer side of the ankle, formed by the lower end of the fibula. The word malleolus (), plural malleoli (), comes from Latin and means "small hammer". (It is cognate with mallet.)

matched.name: Subcutaneous bursa of medial malleolus
matched.summary: The medial malleolus is found at the foot end of the tibia.
matched.description: The medial malleolus is found at the foot end of the tibia. The medial surface of the lower extremity of tibia is prolonged downward to form a strong pyramidal process, flattened from without inward - the medial malleolus. The medial surface of this process is convex and subcutaneous. The lateral or articular surface is smooth and slightly concave, and articulates with the talus.

matched.name: Anterior talocalcaneal ligament

matched.description: The anterior talocalcaneal ligament (anterior calcaneo-astragaloid ligament or anterior interosseous ligament) is a ligament in the foot. The anterior talocalcaneal ligament extends from the front and lateral surface of the neck of the talus to the sinus tarsi of the calcaneus. It forms the posterior boundary of the talocalcaneonavicular joint. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anterior_talocalcaneal_ligament

matched.name: Articular capsules of distal interphalangeal joints of foot
matched.summary: The foot (plural: feet) is an anatomical structure found in many vertebrates.
matched.description: The foot (plural: feet) is an anatomical structure found in many vertebrates. It is the terminal portion of a limb which bears weight and allows locomotion. In many animals with feet, the foot is a separate organ at the terminal part of the leg made up of one or more segments or bones, generally including claws or nails.

matched.name: Articular capsules of metatarsophalangeal joints
matched.summary: The metatarsophalangeal joints (MTP joints), also informally known as toe knuckles, are the joints between the metatarsal bones of the foot and...
matched.description: The metatarsophalangeal joints (MTP joints), also informally known as toe knuckles, are the joints between the metatarsal bones of the foot and the proximal bones (proximal phalanges) of the toes. They are condyloid joints, meaning that an elliptical or rounded surface (of the metatarsal bones) comes close to a shallow cavity (of the proximal phalanges). The ligaments are the plantar and two collateral.

matched.name: Extensor hallucis longus
matched.summary: The extensor hallucis longus muscle is a thin skeletal muscle, situated between the tibialis anterior and the extensor digitorum longus.
matched.description: The extensor hallucis longus muscle is a thin skeletal muscle, situated between the tibialis anterior and the extensor digitorum longus. It extends the big toe and dorsiflects the foot. It also assists with foot eversion and inversion.
actions: extends big toe and dorsiflects the foot

attachments.origin: Middle part of anterior surface of fibula, interosseous membrane
attachments.insertion: Base of distal phalanx of great toe

matched.innervation: The extensor hallucis longus muscle is supplied by the deep fibular nerve, a branch of common fibular nerve, which includes L4, L5, and S1 spinal nerve roots.

matched.name: Fifth metatarsal bone
matched.summary: The metatarsal bones, or metatarsus are a group of five long bones in the foot, located between the tarsal bones of the hind- and mid-foot and the...
matched.description: The metatarsal bones, or metatarsus are a group of five long bones in the foot, located between the tarsal bones of the hind- and mid-foot and the phalanges of the toes. Lacking individual names, the metatarsal bones are numbered from the medial side (the side of the great toe): the first, second, third, fourth, and fifth metatarsal (often depicted with Roman numerals).
matched.articulations: one or more of the tarsal bones at the tarsometatarsal joints, and the head with one of the first row of phalanges at the metatarsophalangeal joints

matched.name: Flexor hallucis longus
matched.summary: The flexor hallucis longus muscle (FHL) is one of the three deep muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg that attaches to the plantar...
matched.description: The flexor hallucis longus muscle (FHL) is one of the three deep muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg that attaches to the plantar surface of the distal phalanx of the great toe. The other deep muscles are the flexor digitorum longus and tibialis posterior; the tibialis posterior is the most powerful of these deep muscles. All three muscles are innervated by the tibial nerve which comprises half of the sciatic nerve.

matched.name: Lateral talocalcaneal ligament
matched.summary: The lateral talocalcaneal ligament (external calcaneo-astragaloid ligament) is a ligament in the ankle.
matched.description: The lateral talocalcaneal ligament (external calcaneo-astragaloid ligament) is a ligament in the ankle. It is a short, strong fasciculus, passing from the lateral surface of the talus, immediately beneath its fibular facet to the lateral surface of the calcaneus. It is placed in front of, but on a deeper plane than, the calcaneofibular ligament, with the fibers of which it is parallel. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lateral_talocalcaneal_ligament

matched.name: Lumbrical muscles of foot
matched.summary: The lumbricals are four small skeletal muscles, accessory to the tendons of the flexor digitorum longus muscle.
matched.description: The lumbricals are four small skeletal muscles, accessory to the tendons of the flexor digitorum longus muscle. They are numbered from the medial side of the foot.

attachments.origin: tendons of the flexor digitorum longus muscle, as far back as their angles of division, each springing from two tendons, except the first
attachments.insertion: extensor hoods of the phalanges, thus creating extension at the inter-phalangeal (PIP and DIP) joints

matched.innervation: The most medial lumbrical is innervated by the medial plantar nerve while the remaining three lumbricals are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

matched.name: Plantar tendon sheath of fibularis longus muscle
matched.summary: In human anatomy, the fibularis longus (also known as peroneus longus) is a superficial muscle in the lateral compartment of the leg, and acts to...
matched.description: In human anatomy, the fibularis longus (also known as peroneus longus) is a superficial muscle in the lateral compartment of the leg, and acts to evert and plantarflex the ankle. The muscle, the longest and most superficial of the three peroneus muscles, is attached proximally to the head of the fibula and its 'belly' runs down most of this bone.

matched.name: Plantaris muscle
matched.summary: The plantaris is one of the superficial muscles of the superficial posterior compartment of the leg, one of the fascial compartments of the leg.
matched.description: The plantaris is one of the superficial muscles of the superficial posterior compartment of the leg, one of the fascial compartments of the leg. It is composed of a thin muscle belly and a long thin tendon. While not as thick as the achilles tendon, the plantaris tendon (which tends to be between 30â€“45 centimetres (12â€“18 in) in length) is the longest tendon in the human body.

matched.innervation: The plantaris muscle is innervated by the tibial nerve, a branch of the sciatic nerve in the sacral plexus.

matched.name: Quadratus plantae muscle
matched.summary: The quadratus plantae (flexor accessorius) is separated from the muscles of the first layer by the lateral plantar vessels and nerve.
matched.description: The quadratus plantae (flexor accessorius) is separated from the muscles of the first layer by the lateral plantar vessels and nerve. It acts to aid in flexing the 2nd to 5th toes (offsetting the oblique pull of the flexor digitorum longus) and is one of the few muscles in the foot with no homolog in the hand.

matched.name: Second metatarsal bone
matched.summary: The metatarsal bones, or metatarsus are a group of five long bones in the foot, located between the tarsal bones of the hind- and mid-foot and the...
matched.description: The metatarsal bones, or metatarsus are a group of five long bones in the foot, located between the tarsal bones of the hind- and mid-foot and the phalanges of the toes. Lacking individual names, the metatarsal bones are numbered from the medial side (the side of the great toe): the first, second, third, fourth, and fifth metatarsal (often depicted with Roman numerals).
matched.articulations: one or more of the tarsal bones at the tarsometatarsal joints, and the head with one of the first row of phalanges at the metatarsophalangeal joints

matched.description: In the footâ€”the first metatarsal bone usually has two sesamoid bones at its connection to the big toe (both within the tendon of flexor hallucis brevis). In some people, only a single sesamoid is found on the first metatarsal bone. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sesamoid_bone

matched.name: Talus
matched.summary: The talus (Latin for ankle), talus bone, astragalus , or ankle bone is one of the group of foot bones known as the tarsus.
matched.description: The talus (Latin for ankle), talus bone, astragalus , or ankle bone is one of the group of foot bones known as the tarsus. The tarsus forms the lower part of the ankle joint. It transmits the entire weight of the body from the lower legs to the foot. The talus has joints with the two bones of the lower leg, the tibia and thinner fibula.

matched.name: Tendon sheath of extensor hallucis longus
matched.summary: The extensor hallucis longus muscle is a thin skeletal muscle, situated between the tibialis anterior and the extensor digitorum longus.
matched.description: The extensor hallucis longus muscle is a thin skeletal muscle, situated between the tibialis anterior and the extensor digitorum longus. It extends the big toe and dorsiflects the foot. It also assists with foot eversion and inversion.
actions: extends big toe and dorsiflects the foot

attachments.origin: anterior surface of the fibula for about the middle two-fourths of its extent, medial to the origin of the extensor digitorum longus muscle

matched.innervation: The extensor hallucis longus muscle is supplied by the deep fibular nerve, a branch of common fibular nerve, which includes L4, L5, and S1 spinal nerve roots.

matched.name: Tendon sheath of flexor hallucis longus
matched.summary: The flexor hallucis longus muscle (FHL) is one of the three deep muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg that attaches to the plantar...
matched.description: The flexor hallucis longus muscle (FHL) is one of the three deep muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg that attaches to the plantar surface of the distal phalanx of the great toe. The other deep muscles are the flexor digitorum longus and tibialis posterior; the tibialis posterior is the most powerful of these deep muscles. All three muscles are innervated by the tibial nerve which comprises half of the sciatic nerve.

matched.description: The transverse head (Transversus pedis) is a narrow, flat fasciculus which arises from the plantar metatarsophalangeal ligaments of the third, fourth, and fifth toes (sometimes only from the third and fourth), and from the transverse ligament of the metatarsals. It is inserted into the lateral side of the base of the first phalanx of the great toe, its fibers blending with the tendon of insertion of the oblique head.

matched.name: Articular capsule of knee joint
matched.summary: In humans and other primates, the knee joins the thigh with the leg and consists of two joints: one between the femur and tibia (tibiofemoral...
matched.description: In humans and other primates, the knee joins the thigh with the leg and consists of two joints: one between the femur and tibia (tibiofemoral joint), and one between the femur and patella (patellofemoral joint). It is the largest joint in the human body. The knee is a modified hinge joint, which permits flexion and extension as well as slight internal and external rotation.
